body: LGTM, will merge.
@shravanmn Do you want to merge?
Yep, on it
@shravanmn @markusweimer I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
LGTM will merge

@johnyangk It seems unavailable to label on the nodes in CLIMiniCluster. 

So I added a yarn node labeling test as a yarn test, rather than a unit test. You can run this by executing `bin/yarnnodelabeltest.sh`.
@scan3 Can you update this branch to resolve conflicts?
@bgchun I resolved conflicts and rebased my repository.
@scan3 Could you take a look at my comment? Thank you :)
@acraghav Looks like this pull request is superseded by #1363; if this is the case, please close this pull request.

@scan3 Did you also check if tests in REEF .NET pass? AppVeyor build failed.

Also, could you address @jooykim's comments? She's a client that will use this feature. :)
@jooykim I've just implemented `Set<String> getNodeLabelExpressions()` on `EvaluatorDescriptor` class. I will push here after testing.
@bgchun I didn't change anything on .Net side. I will check whether it is a transient failure.
@acraghav, I assume this was subsumed by one of @jwang98052 's recent PRs? If so, can you please close this one?

@scan3 I left comments. Could you address them? 

Can you also update your PR description, which does not have enough information? It would be great if you also add descriptions on the tests included in the PR description.
@motus Thanks. Keep them coming. :)

@scan3 Can you check the AppVeyor failure and report which test fails? Thanks.
(In PR https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/1365, there is no test failure.)

@bgchun Thank you for your review. 

`Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.IMRU.TestFailMapperTasksOnDispose.TestFailedMapperOnLocalRuntime` seems to be a transient failure.
@bgchun @motus Thank you for your review! I've addressed your comments and tested on my cluster. :)

@scan3 I left more comments. Could you address them?
@motus Let me know when you're happy with this PR.
@dougmsft Thanks for the PR. I left comments, too.
@Ivanidzo4ka a gentle ping: please rebase so I can merge your PR
OK I am done with the bash script fix. Please take a look at PR #1366, and you can remove updates to `runyarntests.sh` from your PR
LGTM. I will merge this PR.
@scan3 Can you update this PR? I merged #1366 from @motus.
I addressed all of the comments. I will pay more attention to the spelling.
@bgchun @motus Thank you! I've addressed your new comments and rebased this PR after #1366.
@markusweimer Thanks for the comments. Which way do you prefer?
@scan3 Can you reflect Markus's comments?
Running unit tests now. Will do another round of reviews shortly.

@motus Do you have a preference? @markusweimer suggested the following: "either more generic in the common API (e.g. a generic Map<String, String> in resource requests OR to move this to the YARN specific APIs".
@bgchun I think the generic approach would be nicer. later we can have labels in local mode at least
@bgchun @motus @markusweimer Thank you for sharing your ideas. I will reflect it soon.
@bgchun @motus @markusweimer Thank you for sharing your ideas. I will reflect them soon.
Of course. I just don't know how the website publishing process works. Every time I tried, I deleted parts of it by accident :)
@markusweimer I will publish the website if it is merged :)
@DifferentSC Thank you for reviewing my work! I'll check the things you reviewed.
LGTM. I will merge this PR.
@motus @markusweimer I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!
Close it for now until we find root cause.
@markusweimer Any more comments? I have pushed update.
Also, what do we do with PR #1352? It apparently implements the same functionality.
@motus, This PL is built on IYarnREEFClient interface we introduced, with bug fixes and testing added that will replace  #1352 which should be closed.
I have pushed the update. Please have another look.

This API is added on IREEFClient but we would like to add it to the new interface IYARNREEFClient.
There is no test for this API.
The API itself has a bug that don't work. 

It is superseded by #1363. This PL should be closed.
This PL is superseded by #1361, all the review  comments have been addressed in that PL. This one should be closed.

I had to make some fairly large changes in the MultiAsyncToSync class due to a race condition I found. The condition lock has to be held when the asynchronous processing starts so it is not possible to wake the sleeper for he goes to sleep.
@scan3 Any update?
@bgchun Sorry, I've updated but not tested yet because of some trouble on my cluster.
@motus I appreciate for your kind and precise review! I'll check out all about these. thanks a lot!
@bgchun @markusweimer I have addressed your comments. Would you please look at the code once again? Thanks!

Thanks a lot for your detailed comments, @motus! We have decided to split this issue into two, by making a new JIRA issue for refactoring and changing styles of `Transport`. @nhne will work on implementing HTTP transport after the refactoring is done. Thanks!
@markusweimer Did @scan3 address your concern?
Julia Wang has her own pull request for this.
@motus Have addressed review comments and pushed the change. Thanks!
@motus Have addressed your review comments. Thanks!
I also moved all of the call management to the block method and added a number of comments to clarify all of the assumptions.
@motus I have addressed your review comments and pushed the change. Thanks!
The changes are queued.
Okay I am implementing that now.

Okay have a look. I cleaned up SimpleCondition in a way that you could use it to implement MultiAsyncToSync using FutureTasks<>, but this would take more code since lambdas are not available in Java 7. The nice part is that it encapsulates all of the complexity of a condition variable and gives the caller a way to call async code inside the lock.

I have changed the API to return bool which indicate if kill is successful or not. I do think user need examples for Yarn related APIs. There are related questions asked by our clients again and again. have example would help a lot. 
Example usually shows happy scenarios. For test invalid cases, yes, we should put them into test cases. However, .Net now doesn't run test on Yarn as we still have some unresolved issues. We have REEF-1541 opened for it. Also Yarn cluster doesn't have test framework set up for running the .Net test. We should add more Yarn tests after the issues are resolved.
@motus Have addressed your review comments and pushed the change.
@taegeonum Thanks for sharing detailed review! I'll check all you mentioned above. Thank you.

On my PC the race condition test fails for `nTasks = 100` and thread pool size `100`:
```
Aug 22, 2017 8:52:10 PM org.apache.reef.util.AsynchronousIncrementer call
INFO: Releasing caller...
Aug 22, 2017 8:52:10 PM org.apache.reef.util.MultiAsyncToSync block
SEVERE: Call timed out on identifier [97]
Aug 22, 2017 8:52:10 PM org.apache.reef.util.MultiAsyncToSync block
SEVERE: Call timed out on identifier [99]

   . . .

Aug 22, 2017 8:52:10 PM org.apache.reef.util.SynchronousApi apiCall
INFO: Call timed out...
Aug 22, 2017 8:52:10 PM org.apache.reef.util.AsynchronousIncrementer call
INFO: Releasing caller...

   . . .

Aug 22, 2017 8:52:10 PM org.apache.reef.util.SynchronousApi close
INFO: Caught exception waiting for completion...
java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: org.apache.reef.util.exception.InvalidIdentifierException: Unknown blocked caller identifier = 99
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.report(FutureTask.java:122)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.get(FutureTask.java:192)
	at org.apache.reef.util.SynchronousApi.close(MultiAsyncToSyncTest.java:152)
	at org.apache.reef.util.MultiAsyncToSyncTest.testRaceConditions(MultiAsyncToSyncTest.java:267)
        ...
Caused by: org.apache.reef.util.exception.InvalidIdentifierException: Unknown blocked caller identifier = 99
	at org.apache.reef.util.MultiAsyncToSync.getSleeper(MultiAsyncToSync.java:155)
	at org.apache.reef.util.MultiAsyncToSync.release(MultiAsyncToSync.java:106)
	at org.apache.reef.util.AsynchronousIncrementer.call(MultiAsyncToSyncTest.java:71)
	at org.apache.reef.util.AsynchronousIncrementer.call(MultiAsyncToSyncTest.java:40)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)


java.lang.AssertionError: Input must be incremented by one 
Expected :28
Actual   :0

	at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
	at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:743)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:118)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:555)
	at org.apache.reef.util.MultiAsyncToSyncTest.testRaceConditions(MultiAsyncToSyncTest.java:265)
        ...
```
I am currently looking at some of the test cases to ensure the futures are working as I expect. I may switch them to threads.

As far as the results you are seeing, I believe it is appropriate. When I run 100/100, I do not see the problem as I am on a 16 core Azure VM. However, I do see the same result at 400/400. This is explained by the fact you most likely have a 4 or 8 core machine and there is not enough cores to run all 100 tasks before some start timing out. I suspect if you double or triple the timeoutPeriodSeonds variable in the test the timeouts will disappear.

However, I am still looking at some other test issues so I do not want to commit until I resolve those.
@motus @markusweimer Have addressed your review comments and pushed in the change.

Okay, at this point I believe the behavior is correct. I made some small changes to the tests to verify some details. I also added a check to make sure release is not called on the same thread as block and I added a test for this. I fleshed out the simple condition class in a form which I believe is quite useful and packages a condition variable in a way such that the user does not have to worry about the complexities of the sleeper and waker. However, I need to spend some more time considering how to best test it. Though it does currently have one test.

@markusweimer
Thank you for your review! IMHO, current API is not suitable for resource managers other than YARN. I've uploaded an updated design doc on JIRA(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1750) could you please review this?
@taegeonum I just pushed a commit reflexing your review. Thank you for your kind review!
The test failure was the infamous IMRU transient failure so I think this review is complete.

@markusweimer I have addressed your comments. 
Now the API is provided as key-value pair. For YARN, I used a static final string as a key because YARN only support a single string node label.

```java
NodeLabelTestDriver.this.evaluatorRequestor.submit(EvaluatorRequest.newBuilder()
    .setNumber(1)
    .setMemory(64)
    .setNumberOfCores(1)
    .setNodeLabels(YarnUtilities.REEF_YARN_NODE_LABEL_EXPRESSION, "mylabel")
    .build());
```
Would you please look at the code once again? Thanks!
@motus Once #1322 gets merged, @scan3 can update this PR to remove redundant code, I think. He's sending this PR to demonstrate his progress for his GSoC final evaluation, I think.

Thanks for the comment, @motus and @bgchun! As @bgchun said, @scan3 is updating this PR for demonstrating his progress for the final report of GSoC. I agree that this PR could be cleaned up after #1322 gets merged.
@motus @bgchun @DifferentSC Thank you for the comment! As @bgchun and @DifferentSC said, I will clean up this PR after merging #1322.
LGTM, will merge.

@motus I have addressed your review comments. Thanks!

@taegeonum Sorry for late response. I was busy for work about GSoC and reserve force traing(예비군 훈련). I'll check your review now. Thank you for review!

Thank you for good suggestion! We have discussed the using `enum` in parameter issue with @DifferentSC and @taegeonum. Unfortunately, current REEF Tang does not support enum correctly by now.

I tested the suggestion but it raises tang exception that 'could not resolve the enum value`.

So for now, I implemented in the way that interface uses enum but, uses string internally.
I'll check about other reviews now. Thanks a lot @motus !

This is error when I tried to apply enum as Tang parameter.
```
Caused by: org.apache.reef.tang.exceptions.NameResolutionException: Could not resolve TCP.  Search ended at prefix TCP This can happen due to typos in class names that are passed as strings, or because Tang is configured to use a classloader other than the one that generated the class reference (check your classpath and the code that instantiated Tang)
at org.apache.reef.tang.implementation.java.ClassHierarchyImpl.getAlreadyBoundNode(ClassHierarchyImpl.java:274)
	at org.apache.reef.tang.implementation.java.ClassHierarchyImpl.getNode(ClassHierarchyImpl.java:261)
	at org.apache.reef.tang.implementation.java.ClassHierarchyImpl.parse(ClassHierarchyImpl.java:171)
	... 35 more
```
@motus can you merge it as is? Thanks.
OK I'll test and merge it now.

Oh, that's very unfortunate. I was sure that Tang has support for enums by now! Luckily, this is easy to fix: here's my pull request #1370 - I hope it will help to make your code a few lines shorter 😄
LGTM. I will test and merge this PR.
Thank you @bgchun !
Great work @motus ! I'll fix this after pulling the master. Thanks you very much!
@nhne LGTM. I will test and merge this PR.
@nhne I left comments. Before merging it, I'd like to check a few things. Please take a look.
@markusweimer Are you fine with this direction?
@nhne This change breaks REEF on a YARN cluster. Did you test it on a YARN cluster?
